It is the "Big Guns", but all the oral ones failed me and will not clear the infection.

column1: Infection Occurring During or Soon After an Operation
column2: WCP3-2012, 45-54 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: Started with posterior cervical laminectomy. Developed infection at incision site and had second surgery to clean it out. That recovery more painful than initial surgery. Put me on Vanc initially then switched to ceph? after the debridement. Went home on two weeks of ceph? thru PICC. Six days after PICC removed I was back in hospital with wound drainage. Previous labs (outside Lab Co.) showed MRSA not MSSA but not communicated to hospital staff. Put on Vanc and after four days sent home on 6 weeks IV Vancomycin. I feel like the life is being sucked out of me daily and can hardly function. Could this be the vancomycin??  Incision site healing well, all vitals normal, some pain, but major problems getting to sleep and trying to do anything during the day. Could it be I'm on too much of the Vanc or could it be residual effects of infection?  I'm happy that I'm negative for MRSA but ready to get IV removed. Kinda feel like I've been poisoned!

column1: Infection of a Joint
column2: Happy Camper, 75 or over Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I developed a infection of a total knee joint replacement that was done in Oct of 2010. I was put in hospital on an emergency basis because of severe swelling and redness of leg. I was immediately subjected to a ultrasound of leg to verify a blood clot was not present. When this was verified I was taken the next day to surgery where the joint was washed out w/3 gallons of water via laposcopic. I remained in the hospital 3 more days with an IV of Vancomycin. I was sent home and immediately was started on a home admininistered infusion of med twice a day. The dosage was 300 mi every 12 hrs. The med was connected to a "pic line" inserted in my right arm. I have had absolutely no adverse effects of this med. I've had no rashes, no diahrea. No discomfort of any kind. I am told today that I am doing so well that I can cease the IV tomorrow which will mean I have been on the IV twice a day for 40 days and my ability to walk is now about 90% of normal and I expect to be able to start playing golf again in a couple of weeks. I might add that I also was told to take a small container of Greek type Yogurt everyday to combat diarhea and it appeared to have worked.

column1: Other
column2: 65-74 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: Was treated for unknown infection in knee joint replacement. The replacement knee was  removed, and was in nursing home for 3 months trying to get rid of infection with Vanco injected into port twice a day. I had immediate severe itching of head/burning of eyes.throat/swollen tongue/ringing in ears.itching burning rash over entire body/loss of bladder control and diarrhea. Benedryl did not help.Actually nothing helped all the symptoms I was having. I have been left with colitis which is being treated with Entocort (very expensive). I suspected that I had Stevens-Johnson Syndrome and finally demanded to be taken off this drug. I was told by an excellent Dermatologist that I saved my own life by stopping this treatment. I was very upset that the doctors/nurses in the nursing home did not recognize this as an allergic reaction and continued to inject this into my body. Even the infectious disease specialist did not recognize this and ordered me to continue treatment.I eventually had another artificial knee put in,after suffering and almost losing my life. I try to warn everyone I can, of the symptoms and dangers of this drug...or it can happen with other drugs, as well. This whole horrible episode left me with severe depression, PTS, and other issues.It has been over a year now since this happened, but it will be a lifetime of fear of ever getting into this situation again. The ignorance of the side effects among the professinals who should know better really scares me. I really do believe God was watching over me and I feel blessed to be in as good of shape as I now am, though still left with some issues.

column9: recieved this medication for osteomyletis.  This is the second amputation of the great toe (large one).  First amputation was about 10 yrs ago.  I was treated w/IV infususion for about 30 days and then was sent to a infection control spec and he changed dosage and added some other antibiotics.  It responded well to treatment.  The foot was fine for about 10 yrs.  I got new diabetic/ortho shoes and they wore a hole in foot.  Tried wound care and the hole healed.  A second hole developed and Dr recommended removal of the toe (affected bone in metatarsal(sp).  It has been two weeks on vanco and I have had no reaction (picc line).  I am infused twice a day and will continue.  A xray indicated osteo last week however an earlier x ray and nuclear MRI indicated no problem.  Pathological of the removed bone showed no osteo however as stated above it just appeared.  Will update as appropriate.

column1: Bone Infection caused by Staphylococcus Aureus Bacteria
column2: MBAX, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I was on Vancomycin for 6 1/2 weeks to find out that it had no effect on the Staph infection in my spine.  Overall it had made me sick the entire time I was on it.  I had to pre-medicate with 50 mg of Benadryl before every dose of Vancomycin(1.5G) in IV infused over 2.5 hours 2x per day.  I had to have a very slow infusion rate because I had Red Man's Syndrome.  Vancomycin ruined my appetite and I lost about 10 pounds that I couldn't afford to lose.  I was exhausted and slept a lot of the time.  My skin tone had gone to a grey color and my eyes had big black rings under them.  48 hours after I went off of this drug I felt 100 times better-- If you are put on this drug and don't feel well please call your doctor immediately.  I am now on nafcillin and feel so much better.  Also make sure your doctors do a culture and grow the staph and test to see which drug will be most effective- I lost 6 1/2 weeks of time and am now losing the disc and the vertebrae involved in the infection are going to fuse limiting my mobility.

column1: Bacterial Meningitis caused by Streptococcus
column2: Sugarfee, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I was on this medication for approximately 2days. I was Hospitalized with Bacteria Menningitis; because I have allergies with Pennicillin, ampicillin, Rocefrin and maybe other cillin drugs, I was treated immediately to save my life with this drug for 2 days. Initially it was ok; but then I developed an allergic reaction after 24hrs and was given Benadryl immediately; I was then taken off the Vancomycin the following day. My illness cleared up and I was released from the hospital after 10days. My first week home from the hospital I started to get ringing in my ears; I contacted the Dr. to let him know about this side affect and he told me that yes this is one of the side effects to this medication and it usually happens in children; however most often it usually effects both ears. Since it only affected my left ear I should be very happy I only lost my hearing it could have been my life. I was very upset in his response because this information was not explained to my husband nor our children; if it had been they would have sought out a less invasive medication for treatment. Never the less I can only hear from my right ear due to nerve damage from this medication.

column1: Other
column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I was on this med first at the hospital for 10 days, and then at home through a pic line for 14. The first day on the drug, I had red-mans and so they gave me IV benedril. Worked wonders for me, but being on benedril for a month equates to little functioning. For me, it was more of an error on the doctors part that led me to this drug. When a doctor doesn't know why their prescribed drug isn't clearing up an infection - don't let them just go to the most potent and toxic drug. A good doctor will explore other options.It took me going to the Mayo clinic after 4 weeks of pain and anxiety to heal. They diagnosed me in 15 minutes and I was back at work a week later. The original doctors never even looked at the possibility of a viral infection. And even the most hardcore antibiotic will do nothing for a virus. I don't have any lasting side effects from the drug, but it sounds as though doctors don't use it often for a reason. Skin issues can be hard to diagnose. Just make sure your doctor does a culture for both bacterial/viral infections throughout the course. A secondary infection can show up after the initial tests and if not treated will appear to be a "resistant" bacteria. Obviously just my own case and I am not a doctor. But information is power!

My energy level is low; I don't know if it is the medication or the fact that I have had 2 major surgeries (one Nov. 2 and one Feb.17) within 3 1/2 months or that my age is 74 and I don't bounce back as quickly as Ionce did.  My skin feels and looks thin.

column1: Other
column2: tam1966, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I was given this drug while in the hospital emergency room. It was given to me "accidently" as it was actually meant for another patient but we were mixed up and given each others medications.  The nursing staff finally realized their "mistake" and immediately stopped the iv and started me on the antibiotic that i was supposed to been given.  About an hour or so later i was released and sent home but before i could get home i was sicker than i have could ever remember at the time. Severe vomiting and diarreaha over the next 3 days and when we contacted the e/r about it just after arriving home, they seemed unconcerned.  And the worst part about it was that i was to be in surgery just 6 days later. According to what i was told by my surgeon, if I had never been given this drug, i would have healed much quicker from the surgery. But, because i was given it, it took several weeks longer to heal, and lost my job because of having to be out of work for so long.  I now list this drug on my "allergic to" list and will NEVER take it again if i have anything to do with it!

On return visit 3wks. later while listening to my heart a red rash RED MANS, was observed. Vanco was stopped  PICC LINE removed. I now know I'm allergic to this drug, I have never had any reaction to any thing in my life before this.

column9: I was given vancomycin for a staph infection I got after knee surgery. I was put in the hospital and received iv form. After four days of receiving the medicine, my kidneys shut down. Anyway, my kidneys started working after a week of being shut down, but I can't take this anymore or I will have to have a kidney transplant. The reason they take blood everyday is to see if  your kidneys are still working properly. So be careful when taking this medicine cause there can be life long effects.

column2: Jon Blaze, 25-34 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: In the case of Mike, age 45-54, I believe due to his joint pain he may need to be tested for Lymes disease. I have been fighting this terrible disease for over a year now and I am now scheduled for 90 days of Vancomycin IV pick line to finally, fingers crossed-HOPEFULLY beat it.My symptoms leading up to this decision were severe joint and testicular pain, Rocky Mountain Spotted Fever, Mental and physical instability(felt like I was going crazy and extremely fatigued), although I was fatigued I had a disrupted sleep pattern as well as restless legs and anxiety bouts, blinding migraine-like headaches, Dizzy, nausea, loss of sex drive, and vision and hearing sensitivity amongst other minor symptoms. I really hope the Vanco works and I do not get the "Redman Effect". What signs should I look for in the case of troublesome effects to me that could be a danger to my health? I want to hear it from someone who has been through it, not just what Web MD has to say based on averages of affects on the whole sum of responses. Thanks and God bless us all. :-)

column1: Infection of a Joint
column2: rockygurl2, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient)
column9: I have been on IV Vancomycin for over 12 years due to contractures in my right hand due to total body CRPS/RSD. I have to take IV Benadryl pre and post infusion or I break out with what they call "Red Man Syndrome" and believe me, male or female, when I am first put back on it, I glow bright red all over. Tried taking it with 100 mgs. of oral Benadryl to no avail. Unable to tolerate the Vancomycin.  There are a few bad apples apparently who dump their Vancomycin just to take the IV Benadryl. It does nothing for me except stop the Vancomycin reaction so I can tolerate my doses.  It is a very strong antibiotic, so if you find you are glowing bright red, you might want to ask your doctor if you can be given IV Benadryl pre and post infusion.  I was on it for four monhs, then had hand surgery. The Plastic Hand Surgeon wanted to amputate my right ring knuckle and finger but I said no, and I was glad I did, because after being on the Vancomycin for so long, there was no bacteria found, and he even took a slick of bone, and there was no buggies found. Although I did leave the hospital with a hospital acquired gram negative infection. My new PCP wants to put me on Imipenenem and it has some pretty nasty and possible fatal side effects, and the minute I see "fatal" in a side effect, my internal red flag goes up and I will dig my heels in and say no to it. I am sure Vancomycin may have the words in it as well, but it works well and except for the glowing which is stopped by the IV Benadryl, it knocks out any bug growing in my skin or bone, although, I did learn I have Osteomyelitis in my right hand now and that scares me.

column1: Infection of a Joint
column2: 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I was placed on Vancomycin IV for 6 weeks for a serious staph aureus infection in a joint and on the skin.  It was successful in stopping the infection where oral and injected antibiotics had been ineffective. One side effect was a slight itching of my scalp only during the first time it was infused and that occurred only when the infusion rate was increased towards the end of the bag.  I then had a picc line put in and infused the medication myself twice daily for four weeks and once daily for the last 2 weeks.  It was easy to do and I had no problems in using it.  It was mixed for me, ready to use.  I did have blood tests once a week plus once a week checks with my doctor to monitor my body's response to the medication.  These tests showed my body tolerated the medication well and it was successful in killing the infection.  My only real problem was bad diarrhea the whole time I was on the medication, but I do get diarrhea from other antibiotics as well.

column2: LisaMcEd, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I have been on Vanco for a month and I have at least 2 more weeks to go. The first time after my PIC line was inserted the nurse said she would start the Vanco and that the side effects were Red Man's syndrom and itching, starting at my scalp and then going down from there. They said I would have to have the drip set to 1 1/2 hrs but then they saw that I was getting really red and then POW the itching came on. The nurse slowed the drip down even more and gave me Benedryl 25mg. The itching stopped and the redness went away but about 30 to 45 mins later it started again. The nurse slowed the drip even more. Finally I was able to get all of the Vanco in and I was sent home and I was to give the Vanco once a day at home. About 15 mins before doing the drip I would take a benedryl and that kept the side effects away. After 3 or 4 days I forgot to do my benedryl and I had no side effects and then the Drs. decided to have me do the drip twice a day and I still don't have any side effects. I have figured out that if I give the Vanco at least 2 hrs or more to drip it keeps the side effects awa.

column1: Skin Infection due to Staphylococcus Aureus Bacteria
column2: 35-44 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: Had severe cellulitis and was admitted to hospital.  Received IV vancomycin and IV clindamycin every 8 hours for 3 days.  Cellulitis was almost completely cleared up after 3 days.  No side effects, except perhaps metallic taste in mouth.  That may have been due to clindamycin, since it has persisted with oral clindamycin follow-up.  No pain at IV site, and no red-man syndrome.  The nurses did inject the vancomycin very slowly, considerably slower than the rate recommended, and diluted it with a huge bag (at least a liter) of normal saline.  Typically it took almost 2 hours to complete, though that did not bother me.  I did have to urinate often, but I think it was due to the all the normal saline they diluted the drug with, plus all the water the nurses were having me drink.

column1: Infection Occurring During or Soon After an Operation
column2: mozuri, 55-64 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I started out needing a hip replacement. Was done sucessfully but had an infection set in. Had to re-enter the hospital again  and remove infection and tissue. Was put on vancomycin and developed "red man syndrome". Dose was deluted and had no further adverse reaction from the antibiotic. It was a staph infection and the recommended time treatment is 6-8 weeks, depending on the blood analysis taken each week. I did a self administration by picc and found it quite easy to handle. The only side effect I have found is that is seems very hard to fall to sleep. It seems as if I have "restless leg syndrome", except over my entire body. I was prescribed vallium for sleep and percacet for pain. The vallium did not seem to be effective and was then prescribed Ambien CR to help me sleep. I am hoping this will better the situation. Some of the really noticable side affects is that most of the time, I feel like a rubber band wound up real tight and no one wants to let loose of the propeller,especially when it's time to go to bed. Aside from the infection and the continuous iv of antibiotic, I'd say it was a pretty succcessfull proceedure. The doctor advised me that after 2 or 3 days after stopping the vancomycin, the sleeplessness would no longer be a problem. I hope this has been a helpfull input for those who seek information regarding this.

column9: This has been a fairly easy treatment period, after the pick-line was inserted.  It's an easy proceedure to hook the iv up and disconnect.  I've been happy with the fact that it's portable, and easy to take with me when I go somewhere.

column1: Infection Occurring During or Soon After an Operation
column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I'm currently taking this medication via a PICC line (IV) every 12 hours for treatment of a resistant staph infection I received either during or shortly after my hip surgery.  I have no side effects besides having no appetite and being drowsy but unable to sleep.  It's a bit maddening.  They are still unsure if the infection has gone deep within my bone or is a surface infection, but it looks like I am on it for at least 6 weeks.  I am glad that I am able to administer this drug at home, and by myself and that I am not stuck at the hospital for a lengthy period of time to be given the medication as I would have been 15 years ago.  The medicine comes in a pressurized ball and it slowly deflates over 2 hours, minimizing almost all side effects.  This was the last resort antibiotic given to me at the hospital while I was there (and very, very ill while trying to combat this horrible staph infection).  I am glad for the rainforest and Borneo and the fact that we do have this medication - now doctors need to stop using it unless absolutely necessary so staph doesn't wipe out the entire population of earth.

column9: I definitely got the "red man syndrome" and what's worse...I'm also highly allergic to the medication. When they started the IV I got the feeling that fire ants were on my scalp. I had an uncontrollable urge to scratch my scalp. Even when they slowed down the rate of the IV, the severe ichyness continued. I had to be given Benedryl to combat that. I never want anything to do with this med again!

column1: Infection of Bone
column2: TEQILA1, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Caregiver)
column9: I WANT TO GIVE MY OPINION, MY OWN EXPERIENCEWITH THIS DRUG, IS THAT THERE IS POOR FOLLOWING UP WITH LEVELS IN THE BLOOD, THEREFORE MAKING THE THERAPY A LITTLE HARDER TO BE MORE EFFECTIVE THAN IT SHOULD BE.

column1: Skin Infection due to Staphylococcus Epidermidis Bacteria
column2: Devon1990, 13-18 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: i was admitted into the hospital because i had a skin infection due to a hardware surgery, i was then prescribed vanco via picc line at first i had red man syndrome, then they made the time longer. but about two weeks into the dose i started getting a itchy rash all over my body it began to spread so i went to the er and they took me off of they vanco, i then called my skin doctor and he denied prescribing the vanco to me i was very disappointed and itchy i am also having a hard time getting rid of the rash.

column1: Bacterial Infection of Blood or Tissues affecting the Whole Body
column2: highoctanek, 65-74 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: I have had this medicine injected by IV's for almost one year off and on no more than 3 days off...how long can a person live with staph infection or MRSA  I have an ileostomy and cannot absorb pills, also breast cancer and mylodysplastic syndrome (pre leukemia)  am sooo tired of having to have this every 48 hours...and driving one way 45 miles...lose so many electrolytes through ileostomy have to have fluids 4 times a week...thinking of stopping all treatment??? am 67 years old and only have 7 feet of intestines left  no rectum no colon...hospitalized every three weeks,  had four ports all get the infection, had four picc lines same thing, so am getting very depressed...please help me

column1: Infection Occurring During or Soon After an Operation
column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I had MRSA following surgery and was treated in the hospital with IV vancomycin for 7 days.  The medication and infection made me extremely tired and weak.  No other side effects noted.

column1: Prevention of Perioperative Infection
column2: esmcdaniel, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: This drug was used as a pre-op drug for a hip replacement.  It has damaged my hearing and now I have ringing in the ears.  Is there anything that can be done to reverse ringing in the ears.  Please respond to Susie McDaniel e-mail esmcdaniel@yahoo.com

column1: Skin Infection due to Staphylococcus Epidermidis Bacteria
column2: JOSHSKORN, 25-34 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: When I first had this medication, I had 'Red Man's Syndrome.'  A couple years later, I had a cellulitis infection and the ER doctor told me that I must have vancomycin.  I told him my previous experience with it and he told me that it's pretty common to happen.  However, infused over 4 hours, the "Red Man's Syndrome" doesn't occur.  I'm fighting cellulitis for the second time right now and unlike the first time, 3 weeks didn't kill off the infection, but drastically reduced the redness I was having.  This time, the infection is in the same location but I think I'm having to fight with scar tissue, too which as slowed it down.  My doctor switched the medication and it hasn't helped one bit.  I'm going to beg that I go back on the vancomycin.  I also had a PICC line.

column1: Skin Infection due to Staphylococcus Epidermidis Bacteria
column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I was admitted into the hospital with celluitis (a type of staph)on my hand.  I had an IV drip which caused the Red Man Syndrome.  Once the IV was removed the syndrome went away.  I had enough drip in my system to combat the infection.  Overall the drug did not have any other side effects, and was the right cure for my infection.  I'm grateful to my doctor for the correct diagnois.

column1: Skin Infection due to Staphylococcus Epidermidis Bacteria
column2: jkdoan, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: The vancomycin I took was used to cure a cellulitis infection. I have had 3 cellulitis infections in the last 5 years. Each time I was given vancomycin intravenously (picc line) and the infection cleared up. The only problem was that having the picc line in my arm and having to keep it dry limited me in doing certain things that I usually do daily. I guess I would say it was inconvenient, but it did the job!
